verses.text: A gentle answer turns away wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger.
verses.comment: The principle of responding gently echoes Jesus' teaching on turning the other cheek (Matt. 5:39). Both the literal and spiritual sense point to the virtue of meekness, which is foundational for Christ-like living.

verses.text: The tongue of the wise makes knowledge attractive, but the mouth of fools pours out foolishness.
verses.comment: The wise use of speech builds up others, a theme repeated in James 1:26 regarding control of the tongue. Wisdom here is akin to what Jesus embodies as the Word, communicating true knowledge.

verses.text: The eyes of the LORD are in every place, watching both the evil and the good.
verses.comment: God’s omnipresence is emphasized, as reaffirmed in Hebrews 4:13. This points to divine judgment and care, showing God’s continual watch over creation.

verses.text: A healing tongue is a tree of life, but a twisted tongue breaks the spirit.
verses.comment: The 'tree of life' calls back to Eden (Gen. 2:9), symbolizing restoration, just as Christ restores us. The figurative sense points to speech that brings spiritual healing.

verses.text: A fool despises his father’s discipline, but he who heeds correction is prudent.
verses.comment: Discipline from the father echoes God’s discipline towards His children (Heb. 12:7-11). Submission to correction is a mark of true wisdom and humility.

verses.text: In the house of the righteous there is great treasure, but the income of the wicked brings trouble.
verses.comment: True treasure is found in righteousness, reminiscent of the spiritual richness described in Psalm 112:3 and Christ’s teaching on storing up treasures in heaven.

verses.text: The lips of the wise spread knowledge, not so the hearts of fools.
verses.comment: Wisdom is shown in passing on knowledge. There's also a spiritual sense—true understanding comes from a heart open to divine wisdom, as Peter exhorts us to grow in grace.

verses.text: The sacrifice of the wicked is detestable to the LORD, but the prayer of the upright pleases Him.
verses.comment: This verse distinguishes between empty ritual and heartfelt devotion, showing that true worship involves righteousness. The prayer of the upright, like that exemplified in Psalm 51:17, foreshadows the centrality of inner contrition.

verses.text: The LORD detests the way of the wicked, but loves the one who pursues righteousness.
verses.comment: Pursuing righteousness is a theme which Jesus affirms in the Beatitudes (Matt. 5:6), highlighting both moral and spiritual dedication to God.

verses.text: Harsh discipline awaits those who forsake the way; whoever hates correction will die.
verses.comment: Rejecting correction leads to spiritual death, a theme carried forward in Hebrews 12:11. Growth in holiness often involves embracing difficult chastisement.

verses.text: Sheol and Abaddon lie open before the LORD; how much more the hearts of men!
verses.comment: God’s omniscience includes the afterlife and the heart’s secrets, showing the depth of His understanding and judgment, as spotlighted in Psalm 139:8.

verses.text: A scoffer does not love to be corrected; he will not go to the wise.
verses.comment: Rejecting wise counsel is contrasted with humble acceptance. This foreshadows the humility Christ exemplifies and demands from His disciples.

verses.text: A joyful heart makes a cheerful face, but by sorrow of heart the spirit is crushed.
verses.comment: Joy and sorrow shape one's spirit and countenance, reflecting both inner and outer transformation found in life with God. Compare also to the Beatitudes (Matt. 5:4).

verses.text: The heart of him who has understanding seeks knowledge, but the mouths of fools feed on folly.
verses.comment: True understanding creates hunger for God’s truth, as in Psalm 1:2 and reflected by Christ’s call to seek and find.

verses.text: All the days of the afflicted are evil, but the cheerful of heart has a continual feast.
verses.comment: Inner joy is depicted as an unending feast, reminiscent of the Eucharistic motif in Psalm 23:5. This foreshadows the continual joy and spiritual refreshment found in worship.

verses.text: Better is little, with the fear of the LORD, than great treasure with trouble.
verses.comment: The fear of the Lord supersedes material wealth, echoing Jesus’ teaching to seek the kingdom first (Matt. 6:33). Spiritual prosperity outweighs worldly riches.

verses.text: Better is a meal of vegetables where love is than a fattened ox with hatred.
verses.comment: Love is more valuable than luxury, echoing Paul's teaching in 1 Corinthians 13:3. Genuine communion is at the heart of godly living.

verses.text: A hot-tempered man stirs up strife, but one who is slow to anger calms disputes.
verses.comment: Being slow to anger is a mark of peacemaking, a quality Jesus blesses in the Beatitudes (Matt. 5:9). The spiritual sense points to reconciliation and peace.

verses.text: The way of the lazy man is like a hedge of thorns, but the path of the upright is a highway.
verses.comment: Laziness is a spiritual obstacle, contrasting with the straight and narrow way Jesus describes (Matt. 7:14). Diligence in living rightly opens the way to holiness.

verses.text: A wise son brings joy to his father, but a foolish man despises his mother.
verses.comment: Honoring parents reflects the fifth commandment (Ex. 20:12), which is foundational both for personal virtue and communal order in the people of God.

verses.text: Folly brings joy to those lacking sense, but a man of understanding walks straight ahead.
verses.comment: True wisdom brings clarity to life’s path, as Psalm 119:105 notes, aligning personal choices with the light of God’s Word.

verses.text: Plans fail for lack of counsel, but with many advisers they succeed.
verses.comment: Seeking communal counsel reflects the wisdom of church leadership and apostolic guidance (Acts 15), supporting the need for enduring visible leadership and apostolic succession.

verses.text: A person finds joy in giving an apt answer—how good is a timely word!
verses.comment: Effective, gracious speech reflects Christ-like wisdom and is encouraged throughout Scripture (Col. 4:6).

verses.text: The path of life leads upward for the wise, so he avoids going down to Sheol.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s upward trajectory points to eternal life, prefigured in Psalm 16:11 and fulfilled in Christ’s promise (John 3:15).

verses.text: The LORD tears down the house of the proud, but He protects the widow’s boundaries.
verses.comment: God defends the marginalized and humbles the proud, central themes in both Old (Ps. 68:5) and New Testament teaching about God’s justice.

verses.text: The LORD detests the thoughts of the wicked, but pleasant words are pure.
verses.comment: Pure speech reflects a pure heart, a theme evident in Psalm 19:14 and Philippians 4:8. The inner intent is as important as the spoken word.

verses.text: Whoever is greedy for unjust gain troubles his own house, but one who hates bribes will live.
verses.comment: Greed endangers spiritual and familial well-being, consistent with teachings warning against covetousness throughout Scripture.

verses.text: The heart of the righteous studies to answer, but the mouth of the wicked pours out evil things.
verses.comment: Thoughtful replies show discernment inspired by God’s wisdom, contrasting with impulsive, harmful speech.

verses.text: The LORD is far from the wicked, but He hears the prayer of the righteous.
verses.comment: God's attentiveness to the righteous prefigures Christ's teaching on prayer and fellowship with God (John 9:31).

verses.text: Bright eyes bring joy to the heart, and good news refreshes the bones.
verses.comment: The renewal that comes from good news mirrors the spiritual vitality, like the gospel's announcement of salvation (Isa. 52:7).

verses.text: He who listens to life-giving correction will dwell among the wise.
verses.comment: Embracing correction is essential for spiritual progress and communion with true wisdom, reinforcing community and shared growth.

verses.text: He who rejects discipline despises himself, but whoever heeds correction gains understanding.
verses.comment: Self-discipline and receptiveness to correction are marks of growing in holiness, pointing to the lifelong journey of sanctification described in Scripture.

verses.text: The fear of the LORD is instruction in wisdom, and humility comes before honor.
verses.comment: Humility precedes glory, foreshadowed in the life and resurrection of Christ (Phil. 2:8-9). The fear of the Lord forms the basis for true wisdom and the path to divine favor.
